exercise.title: Euclidean subgroup of the Möbius group

statement.p: Let \E denote the subgroup of the Möbius group \M generated by rotations and translations, that is, transformations of the type z\to e^{it}z for t\in \R and z\to z+b for b\in C. The geometry (\C,\E) is sometimes called "Euclidean geometry". Is (\C,\E) equivalent to the Euclidean geometry defined in ? Why or why not?

commentary.title: Instructor's solution for
commentary.p: No, the two geometries are not equivalent. The transformation (x,y)\to (x,-y), corresponding to the orthogonal matrix \twotwo{1}{0}{0}{-1}, is an element of the group given in , but not in \E. To justify the "not in \E" claim, observe that generating elements of \E (rotations and translations) preserve oriented angles, so all elements of \E preserve oriented angles. But (x,y)\to (x,-y) takes the oriented angle \angle 1,0,i, which measures +\pi/2 radians, to the angle \angle 1,0,-i, which measures -\pi/2 radians.

statement.p: Is elliptic geometry (\extC,\S) equivalent to spherical geometry defined in ? Why or why not?

p.p: No, the two geometries are not equivalent. The transformation (x,y,z)\to (-x,-y,-z), corresponding to the orthogonal matrix -\Id, is an element of the group given in , but is not conjugate to any element in \S. To justify the "not conjugate to an element of \S" claim, elements of \S are Möbius transformations, and therefore conformal, and therefore preserve oriented angles. But -\Id takes the oriented angle \angle XZY (where we use the shorthand X,Y,Z for (1,0,0), (0,1,0), (0,0,1), respectively), which measures +\pi/2 radians, to the angle \angle (-X)(-Z)(-Y), which measures -\pi/2 radians.

statement.p: Let T be an element of the hyperbolic group \H, with a single fixed point p and normal form \frac{1}{Tz-p} = \frac{1}{1-p}+\beta. Show that p\beta must be a pure imaginary number, that is, there must be a real number k such that p\beta=ki.

commentary.title: Instructor's solution for
commentary.p: By , the tangent direction at p on the unit circle is \pm\beta^\ast. The vector \vec{0p} is a radius of the unit circle that is orthogonal to the tangent direction, so the tangent direction is given by ip. Putting these facts together, we have \beta^\ast=\alpha ip for some real scalar \alpha. Multiplying both sides by \beta and rearranging yields the desired result.

statement.p: Prove that all elements of the elliptic group \S are elliptic in the normal form sense, i.e., we have |\alpha|=1 in the normal form expression \frac{Tz-p}{Tz-q}= \alpha \frac{z-p}{z-q}. Suggestion: First find the fixed points p,q, then put z=\infty in the normal form equation and solve for \alpha.

commentary.title: Instructor's solution for
commentary.p:
Let
Tz = \frac{az+b}{-\overline{b}z+\overline{a}}
with |a|^2+|b|^2=1. The fixed points of T are given by p,q = \frac{a-\overline{a} \pm \sqrt{(a-\overline{a})^2 -4|b|^2}}{-2\overline{b}} = \frac{a-\overline{a} \pm \sqrt{(a+\overline{a})^2 -4}}{-2\overline{b}} .
Putting z=\infty, Tz=T(\infty) = a/(-\overline{b}) in the normal form equation , we get \lambda = \frac{a+p\overline{b}}{a+q\overline{b}} = \frac{a+\overline{a}+\sqrt{(a+\overline{a})^2 -4}}{a+\overline{a}-\sqrt{(a+\overline{a})^2 -4}}. The last expression has the form (c+di)/(c-di) for c,d real, so we conclude |\alpha|=1.

exercise.title: Alternative derivation of the formula for elliptic group elements

statement.p: To obtain an explicit formula for elements of the elliptic group, we begin with a necessary condition. Let R=s^{-1}\circ T\circ s be the rotation of S^2 that lifts T via stereographic projection. If P,Q are a pair of endpoints of a diameter of S^2, then R(P),R(Q) must also be a pair of endpoints of a diameter. establishes the condition that two complex numbers p,q are stereographic projections of endpoints of a diameter if and only if pq^\ast = -1. Thus we have the following necessary condition for T. pq^\ast = -1 \;\;\text{ implies }\;\; Tp(Tq)^\ast = -1 Now suppose that Tz=\frac{az+b}{cz+d} with ad-bc=1. Solving the equation Tp = \frac{-1}{(T(\frac{-1}{p^\ast}))^\ast} leads to c=-b^\ast and d=a^\ast. Thus we conclude that T has the following form. Tz=\frac{az+b}{-b^\ast z+a^\ast},\;\;|a|^2+|b|^2=1 Carry out the computation to derive . Explain why there is no loss of generality by assuming ad-bc=1.

commentary.title: Instructor's solution for
commentary.p:
We have
\frac{-1}{\left(T\left(\frac{-1}{z^\ast}\right)\right)^\ast} \amp = -\left(\frac{c\left(\frac{-1}{z^\ast}\right)+d}{a\left(\frac{-1}{z^\ast}\right)+b}\right) \amp = -\left(\frac{-dz^\ast +c}{-bz^\ast+a}\right)^\ast \amp = \frac{d^\ast z-c^\ast}{-b^\ast z+a^\ast}.
Thus we have equality of the two maps z\to \frac{az+b}{cz+d}, z\to \frac{d^\ast z-c^\ast}{-b^\ast z+a^\ast} By , there is some real k\neq 0 such that \twotwo{a}{b}{c}{d}=k\twotwo{d^\ast}{-c^\ast}{-b^\ast}{a^\ast}. These equations (upper left entry a=kd^\ast, lower right entry d=ka^\ast, etc.) lead to |k|^2=1. The condition ad-bc=1 (we are free to choose any nonzero value \alpha=re^{it} for ad-bc because we can rescale all four constants a,b,c,d by \sqrt{r}e^{it/2}) gives |a|^2+|b|^2=k, so we have k\gt 0, so k=1. This shows Tz=\frac{az+b}{-b^\ast z+a^\ast} with |a|^2+|b|^2=1, as desired.

statement.p:
The discussion of elliptic geometry () establishes two ways to construct rotations from matrices. The purpose of this exercise is to reconcile these identifications. Given a,b\in \C with |a|^2+|b|^2=1, let us define the following objects, all parameterized by a,b.
M_{a,b} \amp =\left[\begin{array}{cc}{a}\amp {b}\\{-b^\ast}\amp {a^\ast}\end{array}\right]
r_{a,b}\amp = \re(a)+\im(a)i+\re(b)j+\im(b)k R_{r_{a,b}}\amp = \left[u\to r_{a,b}ur_{a,b}^\ast\right]\;\; \text{for }u\in S^2_\Quat
T_{a,b} \amp = \left[z\to \frac{az+b}{-b^\ast z+a^\ast}\right] \;\;\text{for }z\in \extC R_{T_{a,b}} \amp = s^{-1}\circ T_{a,b}\circ s
The above objects are organized along two sequences of mappings. The rotation R_{r_{a,b}} is at the end of the "quaternion path"
SU(2)\amp \to U(\Quat) \to \Rot(S^2_\Quat) M_{a,b} \amp \to r_{a,b} \to R_{r_{a,b}}
and the rotation R_{T_{a,b}} is at the end of the "Möbius path"
SU(2)\amp \to \S \to \Rot(S^2) M_{a,b} \amp \to T_{a,b} \to R_{T_{a,b}}.
This problem is about comparing the rotations R_{r_{a,b}} and R_{T_{a,b}} (see ) and reconciling the difference. The angles of rotation are the same, but the axes are different, but only by a reordering of coordinates and a minus sign.

Let \triangle ABC be a right triangle with right angle \angle C with side lengths a=d(B,C), b=d(A,C), and c=d(A,B) so that the length of the hypotenuse is c. See .
Prove the following identities.
\cosh \left(\ln\left(\frac{1+u}{1-u}\right)\right) \amp = \frac{1+u^2}{1-u^2}\;\;(0\lt u\lt 1) \cos(2\arctan u) \amp = \frac{1-u^2}{1+u^2}
The Hyperbolic Pythagorean TheoremPythagorean TheoremHyperbolic Pythagorean Theorem. Show that \cosh(c)=\cosh(a)\cosh(b) if T is a hyperbolic triangle.
The Elliptic Pythagorean TheoremPythagorean TheoremElliptic Pythagorean Theorem. Show that \cos(c)=\cos(a)\cos(b) if T is an elliptic triangle.

Suggestion: Use a transformation to place C at 0 in \D or \extC, with A real and B pure imaginary. Use the formula d(p,q) = \ln((1+u)/(1-u)) with u=\left|\frac{q-p}{1-p^\ast q}\right| for hyperbolic distance. Use the formula d(p,q) = 2\arctan(u), with u=\left|\frac{q-p}{1+p^\ast q}\right| for elliptic distance. The identities from part (a) will be useful.

commentary.title: Instructor's solution for (proofs of the hyperbolic and elliptic Pythagorean Theorems)

ol.li:
For , for 0\lt u\lt 1, we have
\cosh \left(\ln\left(\frac{1+u}{1-u}\right)\right) \amp = \frac{e^{\ln(\text{stuff})} + e^{-\ln(\text{stuff})}}{2} \;\; \left(\text{stuff }=\frac{1+u}{1-u}\right)
\amp = \frac{\frac{1+u}{1-u} + \frac{1-u}{1+u}}{2} \amp = \frac{(1+u)^2 + (1-u)^2}{2(1-a^2)} \amp = \frac{2(1+u^2)}{2(1-a^2)} \amp = \frac{1+u^2}{1-u^2}.
For , using the double angle identity \cos (2\theta) = \cos^2\theta -\sin^2 \theta and the identities \cos(\arctan u) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1+u^2}}, \sin(\arctan u) = \frac{u}{\sqrt{1-u^2}}, we have
\cos(2\arctan u) \amp = \cos^2(\arctan u) -\sin^2(\arctan u)
\amp = \frac{1}{1+u^2} - \frac{u^2}{1+u^2}
\amp = \frac{1-u^2}{1+u^2}.
